content: I don't want to say what I'm working on JUST yet (though lots of people who were at CT2023 already know), but here's an interesting question along the way

Every finite product category is automatically symmetric monoidal, where the cartesian product becomes a tensor product.

Now say we have a (strong) symmetric monoidal functor FFF between two finite product categories. Is FFF is automatically a finite product functor? That is, if we have a structure map αA,B:F(A×B)→∼FA×FB\alpha_{A,B} : F(A \times B) \overset{\sim}{\to} FA \times FBαA,B​:F(A×B)→∼FA×FB is αA,B\alpha_{A,B}αA,B​ automatically the map ⟨FπA,FπB⟩\langle F \pi_A, F \pi_B \rangle⟨FπA​,FπB​⟩? I'm going back and forth on whether I believe it or not, but I'm not seeing it immediately.

Oh, and be kind if this is obvious, haha. I haven't spent much time trying to prove it at all, since I thought it would be fun to start a conversation here ^_^

Ah, it looks like the answer is "yes". See the baby example here:
https://mathoverflow.net/questions/313600/explicit-left-adjoint-to-forgetful-functor-from-cartesian-to-symmetric-monoidal

Sounds right. So "being cartesian" is just a property of a symmetric monoidal category, not a structure - the forgetful 2-functor from cartesian categories to symmetric monoidal categories is 1-faithful.
So great to see you've joined the #practice: our work team!

Here's a cute question that's come up for me a handful of times. My guess is that there's no good answer, but it would be REALLY convenient if someone does know a good answer (even a good answer that only works in certain circumstances would be interesting)
Fix a monad TTT on C\mathcal{C}C. Is there a way to recognize when an arrow in the kleisli category x→Tyx \to Tyx→Ty is a monomorphism, ideally only referencing facts about C\mathcal{C}C?

In case we work with the familiar group monad on Set\mathsf{Set}Set, this would give a categorical way of understanding embeddings between free groups. This is already a nontrivial problem, which makes me doubt any kind of simple answer... But maybe there's a less-than-simple answer, haha
I'm just starting to learn about monads, but I would be curious about the (hopefully?) simpler case where one considers an arrow x→Txx \to Txx→Tx.

Chris Grossack (they/them) said:

Fix a monad TTT on C\mathcal{C}C. Is there a way to recognize when an arrow in the kleisli category x→Tyx \to Tyx→Ty is a monomorphism, ideally only referencing facts about C\mathcal{C}C?

the forgetful functor to C\cal CC is a right adjoint, so it preserves pullbacks, so it also preserves the monics. so every monomorphism between free algebras must be a monomorphism between the carriers. the fact that it is sufficient, i.e. that a monomorphism between the carriers must also be a monomorphism between the algebras as soon as it is an algebra homomorphism follows from the definition of algebra homomorphisms in the category of all algebras (usually in the eilenberg moore form) and the fact that the category of free algebras (say in the kleisli form) is fully embedded.

the difficult parts of the question are what is simple and what is nontrivial. it usually helps to abstract away the parts that cannot play a role in the answer, e.g. the presentation of free algebras in the kleisli form. the implementation details often hide general answers.

ps note that the kleisli morphism x→Tyx\to Tyx→Ty is not a morphism between the underlying algebra carriers. it is its lifting Tx→TyTx\to TyTx→Ty. so x→Tyx\to Tyx→Ty is monic if and only if the underlying function of its lifting Tx→TyTx\to TyTx→Ty is a monic in C\cal CC...

which is how we would present it to define its composition with whichever two kleisli morphisms would be testing whether this is a monic anyway. so i guess we could answer this question within the kleisli category itself, if we wanted to ignore my prosletizing about abstracting away the presentation :))

@dusko -- Thanks for looking into this! Unfortunately the presentation is the important thing for my application. I have an adjunction A⊣CA \dashv CA⊣C between graphs and groups, and I want a combinatorial condition on graphs Γ\GammaΓ and Δ\DeltaΔ that is satisfied if and only if we have an embedding AΓ→AΔA \Gamma \to A \DeltaAΓ→AΔ at the level of groups.

We know that all maps AΓ→AΔA \Gamma \to A \DeltaAΓ→AΔ are classified by graph homs Γ→CAΔ\Gamma \to CA \DeltaΓ→CAΔ, which brings us to the question of recognizing monos in the kleisli category.

if we have the adjunction that induces the monad T=CAT=CAT=CA, isn't it easier to look at the category of free TTT-algebras as the category where the objects are graphs and a morphism from Γ\GammaΓ to Δ\DeltaΔ is the group homomorphism AΓ→AΔA\Gamma\to A\DeltaAΓ→AΔ?

Sure, but that's equivalent to the kleisli category, haha. And it doesn't help us find a graph theoretic condition for monomorphism-ness, at least as far as I can see. The reason I find the kleisli category appealing is because everything is happening in the category of graphs. We've just changed the target from Δ\DeltaΔ to CAΔCA\DeltaCAΔ, but that's ok because it's still just some graph built from the data in Δ\DeltaΔ.

Chris Grossack (they/them) said:

Sure, but that's equivalent to the kleisli category, haha. And it doesn't help us find a graph theoretic condition for monomorphism-ness, at least as far as I can see.

i imagine it must cost some effort to not see the answer to your original question from the 3 versions that i just gave:
1) forgetful functor from to C\cal CC preserves and reflects the kleisli monomorphisms
2) direct test in the kleisli itself: f∘x=f∘y  ⟹  x=yf\circ x=f\circ y\implies x=yf∘x=f∘y⟹x=y means that you lift fff and then compose
3) if you are given a resolution of your monad, then the kleisli category is isomorphic with the category of morphisms between the images along the left adjoint from the resolution.
in all cases, your kleisli morpism is a monic if its transpose in the category of groups is injective.

now you say that you want a "graph theoretic condition", but what is the graph theoretic property of Γ→CAΔ\Gamma\to CA\DeltaΓ→CAΔ corresponding to a group embedding AΓ↪AΔA\Gamma\hookrightarrow A\DeltaAΓ↪AΔ depends on what CCC and AAA are, which you didn't give.

@dusko Thanks for the help, then! You're probably right that a satisfying answer to my question will likely involve more specifics of A⊣CA \dashv CA⊣C than I gave.

Also, for future reference, your last post comes off as extremely rude -- particularly the tone of your first sentence. I imagine most people would prefer not to be talked to that way ^_^

I agree with @Chris Grossack (they/them) on that last point, especially since there's surely plenty more to be said about monomorphisms in Kleisli categories (both generally and in Chris' specific case).

@Chris Grossack (they/them) how much do you know about the interaction of your monad with monomorphisms? If TTT (or AAA) preserves them, your life should be a lot easier. How explicitly can you compute these functors? In my experience, it should be easy enough to figure out the answer in the restricted case of finite graphs where you can leverage finiteness, and then to figure out how the result extends (or fails to extend) to the infinite case.

Not categorical, but extremely cool: It turns out that 37 is the "median second prime factor".

By this I mean if you look at the second smallest prime factor of a large number NNN, it will be <37< 37<37 about half the time, and >37> 37>37 about half the time!

I just wrote up a blog post about this: https://grossack.site/2023/11/08/37-median

It turns out to not be very hard to prove ^_^
Great read Chris. I had to think a little bit about why you can multiply the probabilities of numbers having (or not) a certain factor, maybe it is worth explaining why they are "independent".
Super interesting Chris!

That seemed odd. He's occasionally had trouble with his internet service provider, so I emailed him, and he said
